explanation:
The expression \( (2n -13)^3 \) is negative when \( 2n -13 < 0 \), i.e., for \( n \leq 6 \), and positive otherwise. The student incorrectly concluded it is never negative. 

Their reasoning likely assumed that cubing any real number (even a negative one) produces a positive result. This aligns with the misconception that all powers yield positive values, ignoring parity of exponents. 

For example, if \( n = 1 \), \( (2(1) -13)^3 = (-11)^3 = -1331 \), which is negative. The student’s error stems from treating exponentiation as universally sign-flipping, conflating even and odd exponents. 

This explanation directly links to the power-sign misconception, distinguishing it from multiplicative sign rules (e.g., "two negatives make a positive"), which don’t apply to exponents here.
